What's missing about the whole "tidally locked" subject, is that the sun will only stay still in a planet's sky if the orbit is circular. If the orbit is elliptical, the sun will wobble back and forth periodically. In parts of the twilight regions the sun could even rise and set, at the same place on the horizon. so there will be temperature swings, (and a way to tell the passing of time), and there could be day and night.

I've now heard 3 different causes for Io's surface getting energy from tidal forces. 1) Io's orbit is elliptical so the tidal force changes in intensity between when Io is closest to Jupiter versus when it is farthest from Jupiter. 2) Io's orbit is elliptical so it speeds up and slows down as it goes around Jupiter. Angular momentum causes Io to rotate at a constant rate. The difference between these two rates means that the tidal force vector points at Io at different angles throughout its orbit. 3) and now there is something to do with the orbital resonances with Europa? I would like to know more about this 3rd option. Also, between 1) and 2) which is more important? i.e. does the tidal force vector changing magnitude have more or less influence than the tidal force vector changing direction (relative to Io)?

So, if we assume they are tidal locked, and if we assume they have some kind of atmosphere - that's got to lead to some interesting weather around the twilight zone. With the lack of rotation we don't get a Coriolis effect so you don't get the rotational weather that we get on Earth - I would think you would have a nearly constant wind blowing across the terminator. This would also imply a constant transfer of water vapor from the "hot" side to the "cold" side (assuming significant quantities of water are available. ) (again, wild speculation without doing any actual math) leading to a dry side and a wet side. The problem being that the wet side would also be dark - heat would come from volcanic activity and heat transfer in the upper atmosphere, but the lack of sunlight would make it tough for significant photosynthesis - but we do know that life can exist without photosynthesis if there are other energy sources such as volcanic vents.
If the planets are only nearly tidal locked (like Mercury), then it could be that surface water would migrate - mornings would be warm and wet and windy (opportunity for plant growth), evening hot and dry and windy, night cold, wet, and still.

Lots of opportunities for baseless speculation :-)

I'm not completely sold yet on the "tidally locked" hypothesis. TRAPPIST-1's inner worlds, despite their proximity, all seem to be fairly eccentric due to orbital resonance. That could be enough the planets have spin-orbit resonance, which given the planets' proximity and short orbital periods may well be enough to stabilize atmospheric (if and when applicable) temperature.

Now, the $64,000 question to me, thinking about it, is if one or more worlds have Earth-like cores, what are the chances they're close enough to interact magnetically, at least in the sense outer planets may pass through inner planets' magnetosheaths, magnetopauses, and magnetotails? There is almost certainly no life on any of the planets in the Trappist-1 system. This is because the host star is an ultra-cool dwarf star which lasts trillions of years and was probably formed close to the formation of our galaxy. This would give plenty of time for any life that exists on any of the planets to evolve into intelligent life forms who would have plenty of time to either destroy all life on their planet or construct radio emitting devices. as far as I know, there are no abnormal radio signals from the trappist-1 system that we know about. which means either intelligent life never evolved or it wiped out all other life on the planet. if intelligent life never evolved on any of the planets in the billions of years that system has existed, it is unlikely to be hospitable to any life at all, even extremophiles.

one mechanism that might sterilize the planets is the fact that small stars like Trappist-1 are prone to violent stellar activity, much more than our own sun. the kind of activity from this star would sterilize earth and wipe out our atmosphere in a matter of millennia. this could be avoided for planets of about 5 earth masses, since they would have a much larger magnetic dynamo in their core. and a much thicker atmosphere
